details: Basic photo and text portfolio website to practice CSS and responsive design.

details: My first project implementing Javascript logic and DOM manipulation.

title: Meme Generator
oneLine: Async API data calls using Vanilla Javascript.
details: Usage of Reddit's API to provide a picture from one subreddit, and then slap on text from another subreddit to make a random meme.
Note: This application no longer functions as Reddit changed its API polict
Lesson learned: Be cautious in what API's you rely on.

oneLine: Redesign of personal website.
details: Personal website expanded and redesigned to include project cards and contact form.

title: Dividend Rate Blender
oneLine: Javascript application focusing on aysnc API calls and DOM manipulation.
details: A bare bones venture into app development where I combined DOM manipulation, Async and JSON to display and calculate an average dividend yield for chosen stock investments.

title: Worthie
oneLine: First full-stack project personal finance tracker.(Note* AWS database hosting no longer available).
details: Personal Finance Tracker and first full-stack project. I've been keeping track of my finances for years on a spreadsheet. This was my attempt at a more accessible web based version.
Note: the database was hosted on the free tier of AWS for 1 year, unfortunately this shrine of my historical effort is no longer working.

title: Lite-Brite
oneLine: Fun Vanilla JavaScript project with childhood pointillism design.
details: A fun, creative project. I saw the cool stickers and wanted to use them for a project but didn't know for what. Eventually remembered Lite-Brite was a thing, so the idea came to recreate a scene reminiscent of childhood.

oneLine: Redesign of personal website.
details: Personal website with crisper cards, animations and dark mode.

title: More Than Last Time
oneLine: Full-stack workout tracking application.
details: More Than Last Time(MTLT) Fitness Tracker. My first full-stack Angular project that included NGXS state management, NestJS and Mongoose.
Note - test data available on login limited to roughly exersizes, use Barbell/ Squat(Back) or Dumbbell/Bench Press as recognized 'last time exercises

title: Guess Who
oneLine: First major React project recreating the legendary board game.
details: I wanted to build my first project in React and I remembered it came to me that I hadn't played "Guess Who" in years...ahhh nostalgia will make you do extraordinary things...

title: EV Charging
oneLine: Leaftlet map interactive.
details: After completing a couple fun and retro projects I wanted to display a darker, cleaner project, showcasing my improvement in overall design, organization and skills with leaflet and scroll-spy.

title: danbennett.dev V4
oneLine: Redesign of personal website.
details: Redesigned personal website to practice React
A cool idea and outcome, but too much hidden information where a portfolio site should have most things openly visible without going through some hoops(clicks).

title: Turbo Beat
oneLine: Beat and synth mixer using Web Audio API.
details: Beat machine with touchpad synth, and a really cool user interface.

title: Grizzly Dividends
oneLine: Fullstack dividend return projection.
details: Full-stack dividend return projection and visualization using reinvested dividends for an initial investment over multiple timeframes

Lesson learned: Be careful with dependency on public API's. My initial intention was to run intermittent schedule cron jobs which would pull from multiple free API's to scrape financial statements and calculate requisite factors for the business logic of the application. Unfortunately, one of the API's moved one of the endpoints behind a paywall, just like Reddit, Twitter, etc, making the updates for this small application cost prohibitive.

title: danbennett.dev V5
oneLine: Redesign of personal website.
details: Redesigned personal website to practice React

Lesson learned: At the time I was also heavily involved in developing Cashamole, and the design kept flip flopping. Use D3.js? How much? Why not make it like Apple's site? its clean. Too many ideas and and don't think the site ended up looking cohesive.

title: Cashamole
oneLine: Fullstack personal finance web application.
details: A cash-flow based personal finance application to track and monitor cash savings and net assets over time, similar to Mint, but excluding connection to online accounts to allow offline, and totally disconnected financial tracking. Conveniences are not convenient when they frequently require troubleshooting. Attention was given to webtokens, authentication and authorization and user sessions
Lesson learned: Be aware of deployment limitations, for instance started with NestJS version 10, however, NameCheap only supports up to Node 14 and needed to downgrade NestJS to version 9.
Lesson learned: Have smaller, more precise project ideas unless decide I a project is startup worthy.

title: danbennett.dev V6
oneLine: Redesign of personal website.
details: A clean redesign of my personal site.

When the IDE Zed was released, I checked out the website and automatically loved the clean, distinct feel. To bend the Zed site build for a product to more a personal portfolio structure I took some cues from Brittany Chiang's latest(Version 5) site design.

title: Hot Takes
oneLine: Twitter for AI Personalities responding to the news.
details: I really just wanted Owen Wilson' opinion on current headlines, and it grew to a few more fictionalized characters based on existing actors/characters.

Lesson Learned: Although shared hosting Node.js applications are always 'running', they are not necessarily active, and will not run cron jobs throughout the day. I had to run Namecheap PHP scripts as cron jobs instead to hit an API route to process the news headline to ChatGPT to database workflow.

title: danbennett.dev V7
oneLine: Redesign of personal website.
details: A simple redesign of my personal site.
After V6 of my personal site was released, I began to think it was a bit too much, niche theme, and heavy. I wanted something light-weight, clean, straightforward, and long-lived.

title: flobro.pro
oneLine: Flow chart gameplan builder for BJJ, Judo, Striking, MMA.
details: I switchd from BJJ to Judo for a little over a year and wanted to get back into BJJ. I was looking through old instructionals, old books and spreadsheets and thought - 'There has to be a better way to build my gameplan...what has worked in the past, what I can experiment with...' - so I created a live flow chart editor using React-Flow as a library. I also added note taking for users to take notes about class, opn mat, or whatever comes to mind.

Lesson Learned: Dont attempt to create your own svg flowchart library from scrach unless you plan to work on it for a year...well I have a starter, now that my application is released maybe I can get back to it

Lesson Learned: Just because NameCheap hosting offer Postgres, doesnt mean its a relatively new Postgres. I originally build the server using Postgres and TypeORM. Upon attempting my initial foray into devops and deploying the application about 70% through I found out NameCheap only used something like Postgres 5....where nowadays I beleive Postgres 14 is released....and Postgres 9 is necessary at minimum for TypeORM. That stung. I considered switching to Supabase, but the thought of outsourcing my entire server and database to an external platform made me feel like I would eventually need to move off Supabase and rewrite everything for my own deployment. So I just rewrote the server AGAIN for use in MYSQL with straight up SQL queries and no ORM.
